config.task_str: I would like to know Inter Milan's performance in the 2023 and 2025 Champions League finals. Please help me strictly fill in the three sheets in the inter_ucl_finals_23_25 spreadsheet on Google Sheets (the required data is listed in the table; please do not make any arbitrary changes to the column names or row names) based on the data from the official UEFA website. If any data is missing, mark it as "missing". After all the data pulling and verification are completed, directly write the read-only link of the completed Google Sheet into the sheet_url.txt file. When filling in the data, round numerical values to the nearest whole number unless otherwise specified. For “Avg age of starting lineup” and “Avg age of team”, compute the average age at the time of the game and round the result to one decimal place. Note that the values in the “StatsDifference” sheet are calculated by subtracting the 2023 data from the 2025 data for the same metrics.

system_prompts.agent:
Accessible workspace directory: /workspace/dumps/workspace
When processing tasks, if you need to read/write local files and the user provides a relative path, you need to combine it with the above workspace directory to get the complete path.
If you believe the task is completed, you can either call the `local-claim_done` tool or respond without calling any tool to indicate completion. This will immediately terminate the task, and you will have no further opportunity to work on it.
Please complete the given task independently. Do not seek confirmation or additional feedback from the user. You should handle all situations on your own, as the user will not provide any further information.

function.name: filesystem-read_file
function.description: Read the complete contents of a file from the file system. Handles various text encodings and provides detailed error messages if the file cannot be read. Use this tool when you need to examine the contents of a single file. Use the 'head' parameter to read only the first N lines of a file, or the 'tail' parameter to read only the last N lines of a file. Only works within allowed directories.

tail.description: If provided, returns only the last N lines of the file

head.description: If provided, returns only the first N lines of the file

function.name: filesystem-read_multiple_files
function.description: Read the contents of multiple files simultaneously. This is more efficient than reading files one by one when you need to analyze or compare multiple files. Each file's content is returned with its path as a reference. Failed reads for individual files won't stop the entire operation. Only works within allowed directories.

function.name: filesystem-write_file
function.description: Create a new file or completely overwrite an existing file with new content. Use with caution as it will overwrite existing files without warning. Handles text content with proper encoding. Only works within allowed directories.

function.name: filesystem-edit_file
function.description: Make line-based edits to a text file. Each edit replaces exact line sequences with new content. Returns a git-style diff showing the changes made. Only works within allowed directories.

oldText.description: Text to search for - must match exactly

dryRun.description: Preview changes using git-style diff format

function.name: filesystem-create_directory
function.description: Create a new directory or ensure a directory exists. Can create multiple nested directories in one operation. If the directory already exists, this operation will succeed silently. Perfect for setting up directory structures for projects or ensuring required paths exist. Only works within allowed directories.

function.name: filesystem-list_directory
function.description: Get a detailed listing of all files and directories in a specified path. Results clearly distinguish between files and directories with [FILE] and [DIR] prefixes. This tool is essential for understanding directory structure and finding specific files within a directory. Only works within allowed directories.

function.name: filesystem-list_directory_with_sizes
function.description: Get a detailed listing of all files and directories in a specified path, including sizes. Results clearly distinguish between files and directories with [FILE] and [DIR] prefixes. This tool is useful for understanding directory structure and finding specific files within a directory. Only works within allowed directories.

sortBy.description: Sort entries by name or size

function.name: filesystem-directory_tree
function.description: Get a recursive tree view of files and directories as a JSON structure. Each entry includes 'name', 'type' (file/directory), and 'children' for directories. Files have no children array, while directories always have a children array (which may be empty). The output is formatted with 2-space indentation for readability. Only works within allowed directories.

function.name: filesystem-move_file
function.description: Move or rename files and directories. Can move files between directories and rename them in a single operation. If the destination exists, the operation will fail. Works across different directories and can be used for simple renaming within the same directory. Both source and destination must be within allowed directories.

function.name: filesystem-search_files
function.description: Recursively search for files and directories matching a pattern. Searches through all subdirectories from the starting path. The search is case-insensitive and matches partial names. Returns full paths to all matching items. Great for finding files when you don't know their exact location. Only searches within allowed directories.

function.name: filesystem-get_file_info
function.description: Retrieve detailed metadata about a file or directory. Returns comprehensive information including size, creation time, last modified time, permissions, and type. This tool is perfect for understanding file characteristics without reading the actual content. Only works within allowed directories.

function.name: filesystem-list_allowed_directories
function.description: Returns the list of directories that this server is allowed to access. Use this to understand which directories are available before trying to access files.

function.name: fetch-fetch_html
function.description: Fetch a website and return the content as HTML

url.description: URL of the website to fetch

headers.description: Optional headers to include in the request

function.name: fetch-fetch_markdown
function.description: Fetch a website and return the content as Markdown

url.description: URL of the website to fetch

headers.description: Optional headers to include in the request

function.name: fetch-fetch_txt
function.description: Fetch a website, return the content as plain text (no HTML)

url.description: URL of the website to fetch

headers.description: Optional headers to include in the request

function.name: fetch-fetch_json
function.description: Fetch a JSON file from a URL

url.description: URL of the JSON to fetch

headers.description: Optional headers to include in the request

promptText.description: The text of the prompt in case of a prompt dialog.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_evaluate
function.description: Evaluate JavaScript expression on page or element
() => { /* code */ } or (element) => { /* code */ } when element is provided

element.description: Human-readable element description used to obtain permission to interact with the element

ref.description: Exact target element reference from the page snapshot

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_file_upload
function.description: Upload one or multiple files

paths.description: The absolute paths to the files to upload. Can be a single file or multiple files.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_install
function.description: Install the browser specified in the config. Call this if you get an error about the browser not being installed.

function.description: Press a key on the keyboard

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_type
function.description: Type text into editable element

element.description: Human-readable element description used to obtain permission to interact with the element

ref.description: Exact target element reference from the page snapshot

text.description: Text to type into the element

submit.description: Whether to submit entered text (press Enter after)

slowly.description: Whether to type one character at a time. Useful for triggering key handlers in the page. By default entire text is filled in at once.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_navigate
function.description: Navigate to a URL

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_navigate_back
function.description: Go back to the previous page

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_navigate_forward
function.description: Go forward to the next page

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_network_requests
function.description: Returns all network requests since loading the page

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_take_screenshot
function.description: Take a screenshot of the current page. You can't perform actions based on the screenshot, use browser_snapshot for actions.

raw.description: Whether to return without compression (in PNG format). Default is false, which returns a JPEG image.

filename.description: File name to save the screenshot to. Defaults to `page-{timestamp}.{png|jpeg}` if not specified.

element.description: Human-readable element description used to obtain permission to screenshot the element. If not provided, the screenshot will be taken of viewport. If element is provided, ref must be provided too.

ref.description: Exact target element reference from the page snapshot. If not provided, the screenshot will be taken of viewport. If ref is provided, element must be provided too.

fullPage.description: When true, takes a screenshot of the full scrollable page, instead of the currently visible viewport. Cannot be used with element screenshots.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_snapshot
function.description: Capture accessibility snapshot of the current page. The snapshot is divided into manageable spans (configurable via --span-size, default 2000 characters, or use -1 to show complete snapshot) and shows the first span by default. Use browser_snapshot_navigate_* tools to view other spans or browser_snapshot_search to find content across all spans. This provides structured element data with ref attributes for interaction, making it better than screenshots for automation.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_click
function.description: Perform click on a web page

element.description: Human-readable element description used to obtain permission to interact with the element

ref.description: Exact target element reference from the page snapshot

doubleClick.description: Whether to perform a double click instead of a single click

button.description: Button to click, defaults to left

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_drag
function.description: Perform drag and drop between two elements

startElement.description: Human-readable source element description used to obtain the permission to interact with the element

startRef.description: Exact source element reference from the page snapshot

endElement.description: Human-readable target element description used to obtain the permission to interact with the element

endRef.description: Exact target element reference from the page snapshot

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_hover
function.description: Hover over element on page

element.description: Human-readable element description used to obtain permission to interact with the element

ref.description: Exact target element reference from the page snapshot

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_select_option
function.description: Select an option in a dropdown

element.description: Human-readable element description used to obtain permission to interact with the element

ref.description: Exact target element reference from the page snapshot

values.description: Array of values to select in the dropdown. This can be a single value or multiple values.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_snapshot_navigate_to_span
function.description: Navigate to a specific span in the current page snapshot by index. Each span contains a portion of the page content (limited by span size). Use this when you know the exact span number you want to view, typically after using browser_snapshot_search to locate content.

spanIndex.description: The span index to navigate to (0-based)

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_snapshot_navigate_to_first_span
function.description: Navigate to the first span of the current page snapshot. This shows the beginning of the page content and is useful for starting from the top of the page when exploring content sequentially.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_snapshot_navigate_to_last_span
function.description: Navigate to the last span of the current page snapshot. This shows the end of the page content and is useful for accessing footer content, final form elements, or bottom navigation.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_snapshot_navigate_to_next_span
function.description: Navigate to the next span in the current page snapshot. If already at the last span, stays at the last span. Use this for sequential exploration of page content from top to bottom.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_snapshot_navigate_to_prev_span
function.description: Navigate to the previous span in the current page snapshot. If already at the first span, stays at the first span. Use this for sequential exploration of page content from bottom to top.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_snapshot_navigate_to_line
function.description: Navigate to a specific global line number in the current page snapshot with configurable surrounding context lines. Shows which spans contain the context lines. The target line is marked with ">>>". Use this to quickly jump to specific content found via search results.

globalLineNumber.description: The global line number to navigate to (1-based)

contextLines.description: Number of context lines to show before and after the target line (default: 3)

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_snapshot_search
function.description: Search for a pattern across all spans of the current page snapshot using regular expressions. Returns matches with both global line numbers (across entire snapshot) and in-span line numbers (within each span). Shows which spans contain matches for navigation. Supports regex flags like "gi" for global case-insensitive search.

pattern.description: The regex pattern to search for

flags.description: Optional regex flags (e.g., "gi" for global case-insensitive)

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_tab_list
function.description: List browser tabs

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_tab_new
function.description: Open a new tab

url.description: The URL to navigate to in the new tab. If not provided, the new tab will be blank.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_tab_select
function.description: Select a tab by index

index.description: The index of the tab to select

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_tab_close
function.description: Close a tab

index.description: The index of the tab to close. Closes current tab if not provided.

function.name: playwright_with_chunk-browser_wait_for
function.description: Wait for text to appear or disappear or a specified time to pass

time.description: The time to wait in seconds

textGone.description: The text to wait for to disappear

function.name: terminal-run_command
function.description:
Allows command (CLI) execution in the directory: /workspace/dumps/workspace

Available commands: which, sha256sum, md5sum, env, tail, awk, curl, file, mv, stat, df, cut, unzip, sed, mkdir, diff, clear, realpath, uniq, du, git, whoami, cat, nslookup, head, sort, rm, ping, touch, cp, gzip, tr, history, tree, ps, pwd, basename, gunzip, ifconfig, tar, zip, date, grep, wget, kubectl, cd, ls, wc, dirname, find, helm, echo, traceroute, less, chmod, python, more, hostname, netstat
Available flags: all flags

Shell operators (&&, ||, |, >, >>, <, <<, ;) are supported. Set ALLOW_SHELL_OPERATORS=true to enable.

command.description: Single command to execute (example: 'ls -l' or 'cat file.txt')

function.name: terminal-show_security_rules
function.description: Show what commands and operations are allowed in this environment.

function.name: google_sheet-get_sheet_data
function.description:
Get data from a specific sheet in a Google Spreadsheet.

Args:
    spreadsheet_id: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL)
    sheet: The name of the sheet
    range: Optional cell range in A1 notation (e.g., 'A1:C10'). If not provided, gets all data.

Returns:
    Grid data structure with full metadata from Google Sheets API

function.name: google_sheet-get_sheet_formulas
function.description:
Get formulas from a specific sheet in a Google Spreadsheet.

Args:
    spreadsheet_id: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL)
    sheet: The name of the sheet
    range: Optional cell range in A1 notation (e.g., 'A1:C10'). If not provided, gets all formulas from the sheet.

Returns:
    A 2D array of the sheet formulas.

function.name: google_sheet-update_cells
function.description:
Update cells in a Google Spreadsheet.

Args:
    spreadsheet_id: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL)
    sheet: The name of the sheet
    range: Cell range in A1 notation (e.g., 'A1:C10')
    data: 2D array of values to update

Returns:
    Result of the update operation

function.name: google_sheet-batch_update_cells
function.description:
Batch update multiple ranges in a Google Spreadsheet.

Args:
    spreadsheet_id: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL)
    sheet: The name of the sheet
    ranges: Dictionary mapping range strings to 2D arrays of values
           e.g., {'A1:B2': [[1, 2], [3, 4]], 'D1:E2': [['a', 'b'], ['c', 'd']]}

Returns:
    Result of the batch update operation

function.name: google_sheet-add_rows
function.description:
Add rows to a sheet in a Google Spreadsheet.

Args:
    spreadsheet_id: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL)
    sheet: The name of the sheet
    count: Number of rows to add
    start_row: 0-based row index to start adding. If not provided, adds at the beginning.

Returns:
    Result of the operation

function.name: google_sheet-add_columns
function.description:
Add columns to a sheet in a Google Spreadsheet.

Args:
    spreadsheet_id: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL)
    sheet: The name of the sheet
    count: Number of columns to add
    start_column: 0-based column index to start adding. If not provided, adds at the beginning.

Returns:
    Result of the operation

function.name: google_sheet-list_sheets
function.description:
List all sheets in a Google Spreadsheet.

Args:
    spreadsheet_id: The ID of the spreadsheet (found in the URL)

Returns:
    List of sheet names

function.name: google_sheet-copy_sheet
function.description:
Copy a sheet from one spreadsheet to another.

Args:
    src_spreadsheet: Source spreadsheet ID
    src_sheet: Source sheet name
    dst_spreadsheet: Destination spreadsheet ID
    dst_sheet: Destination sheet name

Returns:
    Result of the operation

function.name: google_sheet-rename_sheet
function.description:
Rename a sheet in a Google Spreadsheet.

Args:
    spreadsheet: Spreadsheet ID
    sheet: Current sheet name
    new_name: New sheet name

Returns:
    Result of the operation

function.name: google_sheet-get_multiple_sheet_data
function.description:
Get data from multiple specific ranges in Google Spreadsheets.

Args:
    queries: A list of dictionaries, each specifying a query. 
             Each dictionary should have 'spreadsheet_id', 'sheet', and 'range' keys.
             Example: [{'spreadsheet_id': 'abc', 'sheet': 'Sheet1', 'range': 'A1:B5'}, 
                       {'spreadsheet_id': 'xyz', 'sheet': 'Data', 'range': 'C1:C10'}]

Returns:
    A list of dictionaries, each containing the original query parameters 
    and the fetched 'data' or an 'error'.

function.name: google_sheet-get_multiple_spreadsheet_summary
function.description:
Get a summary of multiple Google Spreadsheets, including sheet names, 
headers, and the first few rows of data for each sheet.

Args:
    spreadsheet_ids: A list of spreadsheet IDs to summarize.
    rows_to_fetch: The number of rows (including header) to fetch for the summary (default: 5).

Returns:
    A list of dictionaries, each representing a spreadsheet summary. 
    Includes spreadsheet title, sheet summaries (title, headers, first rows), or an error.

function.name: google_sheet-create_spreadsheet
function.description:
Create a new Google Spreadsheet.

Args:
    title: The title of the new spreadsheet

Returns:
    Information about the newly created spreadsheet including its ID

function.name: google_sheet-create_sheet
function.description:
Create a new sheet tab in an existing Google Spreadsheet.

Args:
    spreadsheet_id: The ID of the spreadsheet
    title: The title for the new sheet

Returns:
    Information about the newly created sheet

function.name: google_sheet-list_spreadsheets
function.description:
List all spreadsheets in the configured Google Drive folder.
If no folder is configured, lists spreadsheets from 'My Drive'.

Returns:
    List of spreadsheets with their ID and title

function.name: google_sheet-share_spreadsheet
function.description:
Share a Google Spreadsheet with multiple users via email, assigning specific roles.

Args:
    spreadsheet_id: The ID of the spreadsheet to share.
    recipients: A list of dictionaries, each containing 'email_address' and 'role'.
                The role should be one of: 'reader', 'commenter', 'writer'.
                Example: [
                    {'email_address': 'user1@example.com', 'role': 'writer'},
                    {'email_address': 'user2@example.com', 'role': 'reader'}
                ]
    send_notification: Whether to send a notification email to the users. Defaults to True.

Returns:
    A dictionary containing lists of 'successes' and 'failures'. 
    Each item in the lists includes the email address and the outcome.

function.name: local-claim_done
function.description: claim the task is done

function.name: local-python-execute
function.description: Execute Python code directly under the agent workspace, and returns stdout, stderr, return code, and execution time in a structured format.

code.description: Python code to execute (can be directly pasted into a .py file)

filename.description: Filename for the Python file (including .py extension). If not provided, a random UUID will be used.

timeout.description: Maximum execution time in seconds. Cannot exceed 120 seconds. If a value greater than 120 is provided, it will be automatically limited to 120 seconds. Default is 30 seconds.

function.name: local-web_search
function.description: Search the web using Google Serper API with concurrency control and retry mechanisms. Supports various Google search operators.

query.description: Search query with optional Google search operators.

num_results.description: Number of results to return, default 10, max 50

function.name: local-search_overlong_tooloutput
function.description: Search within overlong tool output content using regex patterns and return first page with session ID

shortuuid.description: The shortuuid identifier for the overlong tool output

pattern.description: The regex pattern to search for in the content

page_size.description: Number of matches per page (default: 10, max: 50)

context_size.description: Characters of context around each match (default: 1000)

function.name: local-search_overlong_tooloutput_navigate
function.description: Navigate through search results using search session ID

search_session_id.description: The search session ID returned from search_overlong_tool

target_page.description: Target page number (required for jump_to_page action)

function.name: local-view_overlong_tooloutput
function.description: View overlong tool output content with pagination and return first page with session ID

shortuuid.description: The shortuuid identifier for the overlong tool output

page_size.description: Number of characters per page (default: 10000, max: 100000)

function.name: local-view_overlong_tooloutput_navigate
function.description: Navigate through view content using view session ID

view_session_id.description: The view session ID returned from view_overlong_tool

target_page.description: Target page number (required for jump_to_page action)

function.name: local-check_context_status
function.description: Query current conversation context status, including turn statistics, token usage, truncation history and other information

function.name: local-manage_context
function.description:
Manage conversation context by deleting historical messages to free up space. Supports multiple strategies:
- keep_recent_turns: Keep the most recent N turns of conversation
- keep_recent_percent: Keep the most recent X% of conversation  
- delete_first_turns: Delete the earliest N turns of conversation
- delete_first_percent: Delete the earliest X% of conversation

action.description: Operation to execute, currently only supports truncate

value.description: Numeric parameter, for turns methods it's number of turns, for percent methods it's percentage (0-100)

function.name: local-smart_context_truncate
function.description:
Smart context truncation tool that precisely controls retained content by specifying ranges.
Accepts 2D list [[start1,end1],[start2,end2],...,[startN,endN]], each sublist represents a closed range to retain (both ends included).
Indexing starts from 0, ranges cannot overlap, must be arranged in order.

ranges.description: List of ranges to retain, format: [[start1,end1],[start2,end2],...], indexing starts from 0

function.name: local-search_history
function.description: Search history conversation records. Support multiple keyword search or regular expression search, return records containing all keywords. Support paging to browse all results.

keywords.description: Search keyword list or regular expression list, will find records matching all patterns

use_regex.description: Whether to treat keywords as regular expressions

function.name: local-view_history_turn
function.description: View the complete conversation content of a specific turn, including the context of previous and subsequent turns. Support content truncation to view long content.

context_turns.description: Display the context of previous and subsequent turns

truncate.description: Whether to truncate long content (keep the first 500 and last 500 characters)

function.name: local-browse_history
function.description: Browse history records in chronological order, support forward or backward browsing. Can choose whether to truncate long content.

direction.description: Browse direction: forward from early to late, backward from late to early

truncate.description: Whether to truncate long content display

function.name: local-history_stats
function.description: Get statistics of history records, including total turns, time range, message type distribution, etc.

function.name: local-search_in_turn
function.description: Search content within a specific turn, support regular expressions. Used to find specific information in long content (such as tool output).

jump_to.description: Jump to: 'first'(first page), 'last'(last page), 'next'(next page), 'prev'(previous page), or specific page number

messages.content: I would like to know Inter Milan's performance in the 2023 and 2025 Champions League finals. Please help me strictly fill in the three sheets in the inter_ucl_finals_23_25 spreadsheet on Google Sheets (the required data is listed in the table; please do not make any arbitrary changes to the column names or row names) based on the data from the official UEFA website. If any data is missing, mark it as "missing". After all the data pulling and verification are completed, directly write the read-only link of the completed Google Sheet into the sheet_url.txt file. When filling in the data, round numerical values to the nearest whole number unless otherwise specified. For “Avg age of starting lineup” and “Avg age of team”, compute the average age at the time of the game and round the result to one decimal place. Note that the values in the “StatsDifference” sheet are calculated by subtracting the 2023 data from the 2025 data for the same metrics.

I'll help you gather the data for Inter Milan's Champions League finals performance in 2023 and 2025 from the official UEFA website and fill in the Google Sheets. Let me start by examining the spreadsheet structure and then collecting the required data.
[{"type": "text", "text": "2023Final", "annotations": null}, {"type": "text", "text": "2025Final", "annotations": null}, {"type": "text", "text": "StatsDifference", "annotations": null}]
Now let me examine the structure of each sheet to understand what data needs to be filled:
Let me get a simpler view of the sheet structure:
I can see the structure now. Let me also check the 2025Final and StatsDifference sheets:

Now I understand the structure. I need to find information about Inter Milan's performance in the 2023 and 2025 Champions League finals. However, I need to clarify something important: there was no Champions League final in 2025 as it's in the future. The 2023 Champions League final was between Inter Milan and Manchester City, and the 2025 final hasn't happened yet.

Let me search for information about the 2023 Champions League final and see if there's any available information about the 2025 final:

The **2023 UEFA Champions League final** was the final match of the [2022–23 UEFA Champions League](/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_UEFA_Champions_League "2022–23 UEFA Champions League"), the 68th season of Europe's premier club football tournament organised by [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA"). It was played at the [Atatürk Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_Olympic_Stadium "Atatürk Olympic Stadium") in [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul"), Turkey, on 10 June 2023,[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) between English club [Manchester City](/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C. "Manchester City F.C.") and Italian club [Inter Milan](/wiki/Inter_Milan "Inter Milan"), with Manchester City winning 1–0 via a second-half goal by [Rodri](/wiki/Rodri_\(footballer,_born_1996\) "Rodri (footballer, born 1996)"), who was named [man of the match](/wiki/Player_of_the_match#Association_football "Player of the match") by UEFA. For Manchester City, this was their first-ever European Cup, and first European trophy since [1970](/wiki/1970_European_Cup_Winners%27_Cup_final "1970 European Cup Winners' Cup final"). Having earlier won the [Premier League](/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_Premier_League "2022–23 Premier League") and [FA Cup](/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_FA_Cup "2022–23 FA Cup") titles, they achieved the [continental treble](/wiki/Treble_\(association_football\)#Continental_trebles "Treble (association football)"), only the second time it had been achieved in English men's football history.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-BBC-7) As winners, Manchester City earned the right to play against [Sevilla](/wiki/Sevilla_FC "Sevilla FC"), the winners of the [2022–23 UEFA Europa League](/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_UEFA_Europa_League "2022–23 UEFA Europa League"), in the [2023 UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/2023_UEFA_Super_Cup "2023 UEFA Super Cup"), as well as qualifying for the [2023 FIFA Club World Cup](/wiki/2023_FIFA_Club_World_Cup "2023 FIFA Club World Cup"); they went on to win both competitions. They also qualified for the [2025 FIFA Club World Cup](/wiki/2025_FIFA_Club_World_Cup "2025 FIFA Club World Cup") through UEFA's champions pathway (winners of the 2021–2024 Champions Leagues).

The final was originally scheduled to be played at [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium") in [London](/wiki/London "London"), England. However, due to the postponement and relocation of the [2020 final](/wiki/2020_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2020 UEFA Champions League final") because of the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Europe "COVID-19 pandemic in Europe"), the scheduled hosts for subsequent finals were shifted back a year, and the [Allianz Arena](/wiki/Allianz_Arena "Allianz Arena") in Munich was assigned the 2023 final.[\[8\]](#cite_note-ExCo_17_June-8) When the [2021 final](/wiki/2021_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2021 UEFA Champions League final"), which had been scheduled to be played in Istanbul, also had to be relocated due to the [impact of the COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_association_football "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on association football"), the 2023 final was given to Istanbul instead, and Munich received the [2025 final](/wiki/2025_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2025 UEFA Champions League final").[\[9\]](#cite_note-ExCo_20_July-9)

Background
----------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Background")\]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Adidas_UEFA_final_footballs%2C_June_2024_07.jpg/250px-Adidas_UEFA_final_footballs%2C_June_2024_07.jpg)](/wiki/File:Adidas_UEFA_final_footballs,_June_2024_07.jpg)

An example of the [Adidas](/wiki/Adidas "Adidas") balls used in the final on display in London in 2024.

For Manchester City, this was their third European final and second European Cup/Champions League final appearance; they won the [1970 European Cup Winners' Cup final](/wiki/1970_European_Cup_Winners%27_Cup_final "1970 European Cup Winners' Cup final") but lost the [2021 UEFA Champions League final](/wiki/2021_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2021 UEFA Champions League final") 1–0 to [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C. "Chelsea F.C."), who were the most recent new European champions, having won in [2012](/wiki/2012_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2012 UEFA Champions League final"). Manager [Pep Guardiola](/wiki/Pep_Guardiola "Pep Guardiola") was looking to win his third UEFA Champions League title and the first since [2011](/wiki/2011_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2011 UEFA Champions League final") with former employers [Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona"), when they beat [Manchester United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C.") 3–1 at [Wembley Stadium](/wiki/Wembley_Stadium "Wembley Stadium"). He was also aiming to become the first manager to win two European trebles, having done so with Barcelona in [2008–09](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_FC_Barcelona_season "2008–09 FC Barcelona season"). Additionally, Manchester City were attempting to secure the [continental treble](/wiki/Treble_\(association_football\)#Continental_trebles "Treble (association football)"), having earlier won the [Premier League](/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_Premier_League "2022–23 Premier League") and [FA Cup](/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_FA_Cup "2022–23 FA Cup"). After [West Ham United](/wiki/West_Ham_United_F.C. "West Ham United F.C.")'s triumph in the [2023 UEFA Europa Conference League final](/wiki/2023_UEFA_Europa_Conference_League_final "2023 UEFA Europa Conference League final") three days earlier, they became the English team with the longest European major trophy drought—53 years since their latest triumph.

On the other hand, this was Inter Milan's twelfth European final and sixth European Cup/Champions League final appearance, having won 3–1 in [1964](/wiki/1964_European_Cup_final "1964 European Cup final") against [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_CF "Real Madrid CF"), 1–0 against [Benfica](/wiki/S.L._Benfica "S.L. Benfica") at [home](/wiki/San_Siro "San Siro") in [1965](/wiki/1965_European_Cup_final "1965 European Cup final"), and 2–0 against [Bayern Munich](/wiki/FC_Bayern_Munich "FC Bayern Munich") in [2010](/wiki/2010_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2010 UEFA Champions League final"), resulting in Inter completing the continental treble; they also lost 2–1 to [Celtic](/wiki/Celtic_F.C. "Celtic F.C.") in [1967](/wiki/1967_European_Cup_final "1967 European Cup final") and 2–0 to [Ajax](/wiki/AFC_Ajax "AFC Ajax") in [1972](/wiki/1972_European_Cup_final "1972 European Cup final"), enabling those clubs to win the continental treble themselves. The club had also contested five UEFA Cup/UEFA Europa League finals, winning in [1991](/wiki/1991_UEFA_Cup_final "1991 UEFA Cup final"), [1994](/wiki/1994_UEFA_Cup_final "1994 UEFA Cup final"), and [1998](/wiki/1998_UEFA_Cup_final "1998 UEFA Cup final") as well as losing in [1997](/wiki/1997_UEFA_Cup_final "1997 UEFA Cup final") and [2020](/wiki/2020_UEFA_Europa_League_final "2020 UEFA Europa League final"). They also contested the [2010 UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/2010_UEFA_Super_Cup "2010 UEFA Super Cup"), losing 2–0 to [Atlético Madrid](/wiki/Atl%C3%A9tico_Madrid "Atlético Madrid"). Inter was also the most recent Italian club to win the Champions League; since 2010 only one other Italian club—[Juventus](/wiki/Juventus_FC "Juventus FC")—had reached the Champions League final, losing in [2015](/wiki/2015_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2015 UEFA Champions League final") and [2017](/wiki/2017_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2017 UEFA Champions League final"). Having won the [2023 Coppa Italia final](/wiki/2023_Coppa_Italia_final "2023 Coppa Italia final") against [Fiorentina](/wiki/ACF_Fiorentina "ACF Fiorentina"),[\[10\]](#cite_note-10) Inter were attempting to win a [cup double](/wiki/Double_\(association_football\)#European_cup_double "Double (association football)"). Manager [Simone Inzaghi](/wiki/Simone_Inzaghi "Simone Inzaghi") was aiming for his first European title as manager and the second in his football career, having won against Manchester United in the [1999 UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/1999_UEFA_Super_Cup "1999 UEFA Super Cup") as a [Lazio](/wiki/SS_Lazio "SS Lazio") player. Their midfielder [Henrikh Mkhitaryan](/wiki/Henrikh_Mkhitaryan "Henrikh Mkhitaryan") was aiming to become the 11th player to have [won all three major European trophies](/wiki/UEFA_club_competition_records_and_statistics#List_of_players_to_have_won_the_three_main_European_club_competitions "UEFA club competition records and statistics") and the first to have achieved that with three different clubs, having won the [2016–17 UEFA Europa League](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_UEFA_Europa_League "2016–17 UEFA Europa League") with Manchester United and the [2021–22 UEFA Europa Conference League](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_UEFA_Europa_Conference_League "2021–22 UEFA Europa Conference League") with [Roma](/wiki/AS_Roma "AS Roma").

This was the first meeting in [UEFA competitions](/wiki/UEFA_club_competitions "UEFA club competitions") between City and Inter. City had won six matches against [Italian clubs](/wiki/Italian_football_clubs_in_international_competitions "Italian football clubs in international competitions"), while Inter had won 16 matches against [English clubs](/wiki/English_football_clubs_in_international_competitions "English football clubs in international competitions").[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)

Venue
-----

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Venue")\]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Istanbul_Atat%C3%BCrk_Olympic_Stadium_1.jpg/330px-Istanbul_Atat%C3%BCrk_Olympic_Stadium_1.jpg)](/wiki/File:Istanbul_Atat%C3%BCrk_Olympic_Stadium_1.jpg)

The [Atatürk Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_Olympic_Stadium "Atatürk Olympic Stadium") in [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul") hosted the final.

This was the second UEFA Champions League final played at the [Atatürk Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_Olympic_Stadium "Atatürk Olympic Stadium"); the first was held in [2005](/wiki/2005_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2005 UEFA Champions League final"), when [Liverpool](/wiki/Liverpool_F.C. "Liverpool F.C.") secured their fifth title after defeating [Milan](/wiki/AC_Milan "AC Milan") on [penalties](/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_\(association_football\) "Penalty shoot-out (association football)").[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)

### Host selection

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Host selection")\]

.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}@media print{body.ns-0 .mw-parser-output .hatnote{display:none!important}}

For the details on the selection of London as the original host for the final, see [2024 UEFA Champions League final § Host selection](/wiki/2024_UEFA_Champions_League_final#Host_selection "2024 UEFA Champions League final").

An open bidding process was launched on 22 February 2019 by UEFA to select the 2022 and 2023 UEFA Champions League final venues.[\[13\]](#cite_note-13) National associations had until 22 March 2019 to express interest, and bid dossiers had to be submitted by 1 July 2019.[\[14\]](#cite_note-14)

While the bidding associations were not confirmed by UEFA, the [German Football Association](/wiki/German_Football_Association "German Football Association") was reported to have bid with the [Allianz Arena](/wiki/Allianz_Arena "Allianz Arena") in Munich, should they not be awarded the 2021 final.[\[15\]](#cite_note-15) The Allianz Arena was selected by the UEFA Executive Committee during their meeting in [Ljubljana](/wiki/Ljubljana "Ljubljana"), Slovenia, on 24 September 2019,[\[16\]](#cite_note-16) where the hosts for the 2021 and 2022 finals were also appointed.[\[17\]](#cite_note-17)

On 17 June 2020, the UEFA Executive Committee announced that due to the postponement and relocation of the [2020 final](/wiki/2020_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2020 UEFA Champions League final") due to the [impact of the COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/Impact_of_the_COVID-19_pandemic_on_association_football "Impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on association football"), Munich would instead host the 2023 edition.[\[8\]](#cite_note-ExCo_17_June-8) Istanbul had initially been appointed for the 2021 final, but after it was relocated due to the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Europe "COVID-19 pandemic in Europe"), they were awarded the 2023 final; Munich would host the [2025 final](/wiki/2025_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2025 UEFA Champions League final") instead.[\[9\]](#cite_note-ExCo_20_July-9)

### Manchester City

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Manchester City")\]

See also: [2022–23 Manchester City F.C. season](/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_Manchester_City_F.C._season "2022–23 Manchester City F.C. season")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6e/Erling_Haaland_2023_%28cropped-v2%29.jpg/250px-Erling_Haaland_2023_%28cropped-v2%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Erling_Haaland_2023_\(cropped-v2\).jpg)

[Erling Haaland](/wiki/Erling_Haaland "Erling Haaland"), who joined [Manchester City](/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C. "Manchester City F.C.") at the beginning of the [2022–23 season](/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_Manchester_City_F.C._season "2022–23 Manchester City F.C. season") from [Borussia Dortmund](/wiki/Borussia_Dortmund "Borussia Dortmund"), was the top scorer in the competition with 12 goals en route to the final.

Manchester City qualified for the Champions League group stage by winning the [2021–22 Premier League](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_Premier_League "2021–22 Premier League"). In the group stage, they were drawn into Group G, alongside [Bundesliga](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_Bundesliga "2021–22 Bundesliga") runners-up [Borussia Dortmund](/wiki/Borussia_Dortmund "Borussia Dortmund"), [La Liga](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_La_Liga "2021–22 La Liga") fourth-place team [Sevilla](/wiki/Sevilla_FC "Sevilla FC") and [Danish Superliga](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_Danish_Superliga "2021–22 Danish Superliga") champions [Copenhagen](/wiki/F.C._Copenhagen "F.C. Copenhagen").[\[18\]](#cite_note-UEFA-18)

In City's opener of the group stage, they faced Sevilla at the [Ramón Sánchez Pizjuán](/wiki/Ram%C3%B3n_S%C3%A1nchez_Pizju%C3%A1n_Stadium "Ramón Sánchez Pizjuán Stadium") and won 4–0, with goals from [Phil Foden](/wiki/Phil_Foden "Phil Foden"), [Rúben Dias](/wiki/R%C3%BAben_Dias "Rúben Dias") and a brace from [Erling Haaland](/wiki/Erling_Haaland "Erling Haaland").[\[19\]](#cite_note-19) On matchday 2, City won 2–1 at the [City of Manchester Stadium](/wiki/City_of_Manchester_Stadium "City of Manchester Stadium") against Borussia Dortmund, with goals from [John Stones](/wiki/John_Stones "John Stones") and Erling Haaland.[\[20\]](#cite_note-20) On matchday 3, City defeated Copenhagen at home 5–0, with goals from [Riyad Mahrez](/wiki/Riyad_Mahrez "Riyad Mahrez"), [Julián Álvarez](/wiki/Juli%C3%A1n_%C3%81lvarez "Julián Álvarez"), a brace from Erling Haaland and an own goal from [Davit Khocholava](/wiki/Davit_Khocholava "Davit Khocholava").[\[21\]](#cite_note-21) On matchday 4, City drew in Copenhagen 0–0.[\[22\]](#cite_note-22) On matchday 5, City drew against Borussia Dortmund at the [Westfalenstadion](/wiki/Westfalenstadion "Westfalenstadion") 0–0.[\[23\]](#cite_note-23) On matchday 6, at the City of Manchester Stadium, the hosts defeated Sevilla 3–1, with goals from [Rico Lewis](/wiki/Rico_Lewis "Rico Lewis"), Julian Álvarez and Riyad Mahrez.[\[24\]](#cite_note-24)

In the round of 16, City were drawn against German club [RB Leipzig](/wiki/RB_Leipzig "RB Leipzig"). In the first leg held at the [Red Bull Arena](/wiki/Red_Bull_Arena_\(Leipzig\) "Red Bull Arena (Leipzig)"), City drew 1–1, with goals from Riyad Mahrez and [Joško Gvardiol](/wiki/Jo%C5%A1ko_Gvardiol "Joško Gvardiol").[\[25\]](#cite_note-25) In the reverse leg, City defeated Leipzig 7–0, with five goals from Erling Haaland, tying a Champions League single game goals record, and one goal each from [İlkay Gündoğan](/wiki/%C4%B0lkay_G%C3%BCndo%C4%9Fan "İlkay Gündoğan") and [Kevin De Bruyne](/wiki/Kevin_De_Bruyne "Kevin De Bruyne"), to win 8–1 on aggregate and advance to the quarter-finals.[\[26\]](#cite_note-26)

In the quarter-finals, City were drawn against German champions [Bayern Munich](/wiki/FC_Bayern_Munich "FC Bayern Munich"). In the first leg, at the City of Manchester Stadium, the hosts won 3–0, with goals from [Rodri](/wiki/Rodri_\(footballer,_born_1996\) "Rodri (footballer, born 1996)"), [Bernardo Silva](/wiki/Bernardo_Silva "Bernardo Silva") and Erling Haaland.[\[27\]](#cite_note-27) In the second leg, at the [Allianz Arena](/wiki/Allianz_Arena "Allianz Arena"), City drew 1–1, with goals from Erling Haaland and [Joshua Kimmich](/wiki/Joshua_Kimmich "Joshua Kimmich"), winning 4–1 on aggregate and qualifying for the semi-finals.[\[28\]](#cite_note-28)

In the semi-finals, City were drawn against Spanish champions and [reigning UEFA Champions League winners](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_UEFA_Champions_League "2021–22 UEFA Champions League") [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_CF "Real Madrid CF"), making it a rematch of the last season's tie at the same stage, which Madrid won 6–5 on aggregate after extra time. In the first leg, at the [Santiago Bernabéu](/wiki/Santiago_Bernab%C3%A9u_Stadium "Santiago Bernabéu Stadium"), City and Real drew, with a first-half goal by [Vinícius Júnior](/wiki/Vin%C3%ADcius_J%C3%BAnior "Vinícius Júnior") matched by a Kevin De Bruyne equaliser.[\[29\]](#cite_note-29) In the second leg, at the City of Manchester Stadium, the hosts won 4–0, with a brace from Bernardo Silva and goals by [Manuel Akanji](/wiki/Manuel_Akanji "Manuel Akanji") and Julián Álvarez. City won 5–1 on aggregate to qualify for their second Champions League final in three years.[\[30\]](#cite_note-30)

### Inter Milan

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Inter Milan")\]

See also: [2022–23 Inter Milan season](/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_Inter_Milan_season "2022–23 Inter Milan season")

Inter Milan qualified for the Champions League group stage by finishing as runners-up in the [2021–22 Serie A](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_Serie_A "2021–22 Serie A"). In the group stage, they were drawn into Group C alongside [Bundesliga](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_Bundesliga "2021–22 Bundesliga") champions [Bayern Munich](/wiki/FC_Bayern_Munich "FC Bayern Munich"), [La Liga](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_La_Liga "2021–22 La Liga") runners-up [Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona") and [Czech First League](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_Czech_First_League "2021–22 Czech First League") champions [Viktoria Plzeň](/wiki/FC_Viktoria_Plze%C5%88 "FC Viktoria Plzeň").[\[18\]](#cite_note-UEFA-18)

In the opening match of the group stage, Inter faced Bayern Munich at the [San Siro](/wiki/San_Siro "San Siro") and lost 0–2, with goals for Bayern from [Leroy Sané](/wiki/Leroy_San%C3%A9 "Leroy Sané") and an own goal by [Danilo D'Ambrosio](/wiki/Danilo_D%27Ambrosio "Danilo D'Ambrosio").[\[31\]](#cite_note-31) On matchday 2, Inter won 2–0 against Viktoria Plzeň at the [Doosan Arena](/wiki/Doosan_Arena "Doosan Arena"), with goals from [Edin Džeko](/wiki/Edin_D%C5%BEeko "Edin Džeko") and [Denzel Dumfries](/wiki/Denzel_Dumfries "Denzel Dumfries").[\[32\]](#cite_note-32) On matchday 3, Inter returned to the San Siro and won 1–0 against Barcelona, with the only goal of the match coming from [Hakan Çalhanoğlu](/wiki/Hakan_%C3%87alhano%C4%9Flu "Hakan Çalhanoğlu").[\[33\]](#cite_note-33) On matchday 4, Inter drew 3–3 with Barcelona at the [Camp Nou](/wiki/Camp_Nou "Camp Nou"), with [Nicolò Barella](/wiki/Nicol%C3%B2_Barella "Nicolò Barella"), [Lautaro Martínez](/wiki/Lautaro_Mart%C3%ADnez "Lautaro Martínez") and [Robin Gosens](/wiki/Robin_Gosens "Robin Gosens") scoring for Inter, and [Robert Lewandowski](/wiki/Robert_Lewandowski "Robert Lewandowski") (twice) and [Ousmane Dembélé](/wiki/Ousmane_Demb%C3%A9l%C3%A9 "Ousmane Dembélé") scoring for the hosts.[\[34\]](#cite_note-34) On matchday 5, Inter won 4–0 against Viktoria Plzeň at the San Siro, with goals from [Henrikh Mkhitaryan](/wiki/Henrikh_Mkhitaryan "Henrikh Mkhitaryan"), Džeko and [Romelu Lukaku](/wiki/Romelu_Lukaku "Romelu Lukaku"), sealing qualification to the knockout phase.[\[35\]](#cite_note-35) On matchday 6, Inter lost 2–0 to Bayern Munich at the [Allianz Arena](/wiki/Allianz_Arena "Allianz Arena"), with goals from [Benjamin Pavard](/wiki/Benjamin_Pavard "Benjamin Pavard") and [Eric Maxim Choupo-Moting](/wiki/Eric_Maxim_Choupo-Moting "Eric Maxim Choupo-Moting").[\[36\]](#cite_note-36)

In the round of 16, Inter were drawn against Portuguese club [Porto](/wiki/FC_Porto "FC Porto"). In the first leg held at the San Siro, Inter won 1–0, with a goal from Lukaku.[\[37\]](#cite_note-37) In the reverse leg at the [Estádio do Dragão](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_do_Drag%C3%A3o "Estádio do Dragão"), Inter drew 0–0 to seal a 1–0 aggregate victory and qualify for the quarter-finals.[\[38\]](#cite_note-38)

In the quarter-finals, Inter were drawn against another Portuguese club, [Benfica](/wiki/S.L._Benfica "S.L. Benfica"). In the first leg at the [Estádio da Luz](/wiki/Est%C3%A1dio_da_Luz "Estádio da Luz"), Inter won 2–0, with goals from Barella and a [penalty kick](/wiki/Penalty_kick_\(association_football\) "Penalty kick (association football)") from Lukaku.[\[39\]](#cite_note-39) In the second leg at the San Siro, Inter drew 3–3, with goals from Barella, Martínez and [Joaquín Correa](/wiki/Joaqu%C3%ADn_Correa "Joaquín Correa") for Inter, and [Fredrik Aursnes](/wiki/Fredrik_Aursnes "Fredrik Aursnes"), [António Silva](/wiki/Ant%C3%B3nio_Silva_\(footballer\) "António Silva (footballer)") and [Petar Musa](/wiki/Petar_Musa "Petar Musa") for the visitors, winning 5–3 on aggregate and sealing semi-finals qualification.[\[40\]](#cite_note-40)

In the semi-finals, Inter were drawn against [local rivals](/wiki/Derby_della_Madonnina "Derby della Madonnina") [Milan](/wiki/AC_Milan "AC Milan"), their first meeting in [European competition](/wiki/UEFA_club_competitions "UEFA club competitions") since [2005](/wiki/2004%E2%80%9305_UEFA_Champions_League_knockout_stage#Quarter-finals "2004–05 UEFA Champions League knockout stage"), with both legs being held at the San Siro. In the 'away' leg, Inter won 2–0, with goals from Džeko and Mkhitaryan.[\[41\]](#cite_note-41) In the home leg, Inter won 1–0, with the only goal of the match coming from Martínez, qualifying Inter for the final with a 3–0 aggregate victory. It was the club's sixth European Cup final appearance and their first since [2010](/wiki/2010_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2010 UEFA Champions League final"), when [José Mourinho](/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Mourinho "José Mourinho") was manager.[\[42\]](#cite_note-42)

Pre-match
---------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Pre-match")\]

### Identity

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Identity")\]

The visual identity of the 2023 UEFA Champions League final was unveiled at the group stage draw in Istanbul on 25 August 2022.[\[43\]](#cite_note-43)

### Officials

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=10 "Edit section: Officials")\]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Szymon_Marciniak.JPG/250px-Szymon_Marciniak.JPG)](/wiki/File:Szymon_Marciniak.JPG)

Polish referee [Szymon Marciniak](/wiki/Szymon_Marciniak "Szymon Marciniak") officiated the final.

On 22 May 2023, Polish referee [Szymon Marciniak](/wiki/Szymon_Marciniak "Szymon Marciniak") was appointed to take charge of the final by UEFA, along with fellow Poles: Paweł Sokolnicki and Tomasz Listkiewicz as [assistant referees](/wiki/Assistant_referee_\(association_football\) "Assistant referee (association football)") and Tomasz Kwiatkowski as the [video assistant referee](/wiki/Video_assistant_referee "Video assistant referee").[\[44\]](#cite_note-44)[\[2\]](#cite_note-officials-2) The four officials had all previously officiated together in the [World Cup final](/wiki/2022_FIFA_World_Cup_final "2022 FIFA World Cup final") six months prior.[\[45\]](#cite_note-45)[\[46\]](#cite_note-46) They were joined by fellow countryman Bartosz Frankowski as assistant VAR, with Romanian [István Kovács](/wiki/Istv%C3%A1n_Kov%C3%A1cs_\(referee\) "István Kovács (referee)") appointed as the fourth official.[\[2\]](#cite_note-officials-2) Some controversy regarding the appointment was raised in early June due to multiple media reports that Marciniak had been present at an event organised by [Sławomir Mentzen](/wiki/S%C5%82awomir_Mentzen "Sławomir Mentzen"), a [right-wing](/wiki/Right-wing_politics "Right-wing politics") Polish politician and leader of the [libertarian](/wiki/Libertarianism "Libertarianism") [New Hope](/wiki/New_Hope_\(Poland\) "New Hope (Poland)") party.[\[47\]](#cite_note-47)[\[48\]](#cite_note-48) UEFA investigated the incident and subsequently decided to maintain the original refereeing line-up on 2 June, having acknowledged Marciniak's "profound apologies and clarification".[\[49\]](#cite_note-49)

### Ambassador

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Ambassador")\]

The ambassador for the final was former Turkish international [Hamit Altıntop](/wiki/Hamit_Alt%C4%B1ntop "Hamit Altıntop"), who was originally the ambassador for 2020 and 2021 finals before those matches were relocated to [Lisbon](/wiki/Lisbon "Lisbon") and [Porto](/wiki/Porto "Porto"), respectively.[\[50\]](#cite_note-50)

### Opening ceremony

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Opening ceremony")\]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/COMBATCHY_-_Espa%C3%A7o_das_Am%C3%A9ricas_%2837663558155%29.jpg/120px-COMBATCHY_-_Espa%C3%A7o_das_Am%C3%A9ricas_%2837663558155%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:COMBATCHY_-_Espa%C3%A7o_das_Am%C3%A9ricas_\(37663558155\).jpg)

[Alesso](/wiki/Alesso "Alesso"), [Burna Boy](/wiki/Burna_Boy "Burna Boy") and [Anitta](/wiki/Anitta_\(singer\) "Anitta (singer)") are the headline acts of the opening ceremony.

The opening ceremony before the match, officially known as the _2023 UEFA Champions League Final Kick Off Show by Pepsi_ for sponsorship reasons, featured Swedish DJ [Alesso](/wiki/Alesso "Alesso"), Nigerian singer [Burna Boy](/wiki/Burna_Boy "Burna Boy") and Brazilian singer [Anitta](/wiki/Anitta_\(singer\) "Anitta (singer)").[\[51\]](#cite_note-51)[\[52\]](#cite_note-52) Hungarian pianist [Ádám György](/wiki/%C3%81d%C3%A1m_Gy%C3%B6rgy "Ádám György") performed a special rendition of the [UEFA Champions League Anthem](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League_Anthem "UEFA Champions League Anthem") as the teams walked out for the match.[\[53\]](#cite_note-53)

### Ticketing

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=13 "Edit section: Ticketing")\]

With a stadium capacity of 72,000 for the final, a total amount of 47,200 tickets were available to fans and the general public, with the two finalist teams receiving 20,000 tickets each, and with the other tickets sold to fans worldwide via _UEFA.com_ from 21 to 28 April 2023 in four price categories: €690, €490, €180 and €70. Accessibility tickets for disabled spectators cost €70. The remaining tickets were allocated to the local organising committee, national associations, commercial partners and broadcasters, and to serve the corporate hospitality programme.[\[54\]](#cite_note-54)

Match
-----

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Match")\]

### Summary

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Summary")\]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/Yokohama_F._Marinos_-_Manchester_City_%283-5%29_-_53075487835_%28Rodri%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Yokohama_F._Marinos_-_Manchester_City_%283-5%29_-_53075487835_%28Rodri%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Yokohama_F._Marinos_-_Manchester_City_\(3-5\)_-_53075487835_\(Rodri\)_\(cropped\).jpg)

City midfielder [Rodri](/wiki/Rodri_\(footballer,_born_1996\) "Rodri (footballer, born 1996)") was named [man of the match](/wiki/Player_of_the_match#Association_football "Player of the match") after scoring its only goal.

Manchester City began the final with [Kyle Walker](/wiki/Kyle_Walker "Kyle Walker") on the bench and replaced by [Nathan Aké](/wiki/Nathan_Ak%C3%A9 "Nathan Aké") in the starting line-up in an unexpected change; Inter Milan started [Marcelo Brozović](/wiki/Marcelo_Brozovi%C4%87 "Marcelo Brozović") in place of [Henrikh Mkhitaryan](/wiki/Henrikh_Mkhitaryan "Henrikh Mkhitaryan") who was returning from an injury.[\[55\]](#cite_note-55) The two sides had scoring chances early in the first half, but Inter's [André Onana](/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Onana "André Onana") made two saves to prevent City from taking the lead.[\[56\]](#cite_note-NYTimes-56) A misplayed pass from [Ederson](/wiki/Ederson_\(footballer,_born_1993\) "Ederson (footballer, born 1993)") in the 26th minute was stolen by [Nicolò Barella](/wiki/Nicol%C3%B2_Barella "Nicolò Barella"), but his shot over the goalkeeper missed.[\[57\]](#cite_note-Guardian-Live-57)[\[58\]](#cite_note-Guardian-Summary-58) [Kevin De Bruyne](/wiki/Kevin_De_Bruyne "Kevin De Bruyne") left the match in the 36th minute with a hamstring injury and was replaced by [Phil Foden](/wiki/Phil_Foden "Phil Foden").[\[59\]](#cite_note-59) The first half ended scoreless, with Inter playing defensively to prevent City from gaining momentum.[\[56\]](#cite_note-NYTimes-56)[\[58\]](#cite_note-Guardian-Summary-58)

[Romelu Lukaku](/wiki/Romelu_Lukaku "Romelu Lukaku") was brought on to replace former City striker [Edin Džeko](/wiki/Edin_D%C5%BEeko "Edin Džeko") early in the second half and immediately produced a chance from a header. In the 59th minute, Ederson failed to collect a backpass from [Manuel Akanji](/wiki/Manuel_Akanji "Manuel Akanji") which was found by Inter's [Lautaro Martínez](/wiki/Lautaro_Mart%C3%ADnez "Lautaro Martínez"); his shot from near the touchline was saved by Ederson.[\[58\]](#cite_note-Guardian-Summary-58) [Rodri](/wiki/Rodri_\(footballer,_born_1996\) "Rodri (footballer, born 1996)") scored the opening goal for City in the 68th minute with a side-footed finish to the right of the net after a pulled-back pass from [Bernardo Silva](/wiki/Bernardo_Silva "Bernardo Silva") on the right to the edge of the penalty area.[\[56\]](#cite_note-NYTimes-56)[\[57\]](#cite_note-Guardian-Live-57) Inter had a chance to equalise three minutes later through a header by defender [Federico Dimarco](/wiki/Federico_Dimarco "Federico Dimarco") that hit the crossbar. Dimarco tried to capitalise on the rebound as well, but his shot was accidentally blocked by his teammate [Lukaku](/wiki/Romelu_Lukaku "Romelu Lukaku").[\[56\]](#cite_note-NYTimes-56) The Belgian striker had his own chance to score from a close-range header in the 89th minute, which Ederson blocked with his legs.[\[58\]](#cite_note-Guardian-Summary-58) The Brazilian goalkeeper made an additional save in the sixth minute of stoppage time off [Robin Gosens](/wiki/Robin_Gosens "Robin Gosens")'s header to preserve a 1–0 victory for City.[\[57\]](#cite_note-Guardian-Live-57)

**Match rules**[\[60\]](#cite_note-regulations-60)

*   90 minutes
*   30 minutes of [extra time](/wiki/Overtime_\(sports\)#Association_football "Overtime (sports)") if necessary
*   [Penalty shoot-out](/wiki/Penalty_shoot-out_\(association_football\) "Penalty shoot-out (association football)") if scores still level
*   Twelve named substitutes
*   Maximum of five substitutions, with a sixth allowed in extra time[\[note 1\]](#cite_note-61)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/2023-10-04_Fu%C3%9Fball%2C_M%C3%A4nner%2C_UEFA_Champions_League%2C_RB_Leipzig_-_Manchester_City_FC_1DX_2797_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-2023-10-04_Fu%C3%9Fball%2C_M%C3%A4nner%2C_UEFA_Champions_League%2C_RB_Leipzig_-_Manchester_City_FC_1DX_2797_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:2023-10-04_Fu%C3%9Fball,_M%C3%A4nner,_UEFA_Champions_League,_RB_Leipzig_-_Manchester_City_FC_1DX_2797_\(cropped\).jpg)

Manchester City's [Pep Guardiola](/wiki/Pep_Guardiola "Pep Guardiola") won his third Champions League title as a manager, and fourth overall.

With their victory, Manchester City secured their first UEFA Champions League title, the first new winners of the competition since fellow English club Chelsea in 2012. City became the sixth English club, and 23rd overall team, to win the European Cup, which marked the 15th time an English club were champions of the competition.[\[62\]](#cite_note-63) Manchester City also completed the tenth [continental treble](/wiki/Treble_\(association_football\)#Continental_trebles "Treble (association football)") in European football history, doing so as the eighth overall team and second English club after [city rivals](/wiki/Manchester_derby "Manchester derby") [Manchester United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C.") in [1998–99](/wiki/1998%E2%80%9399_Manchester_United_F.C._season "1998–99 Manchester United F.C. season").[\[63\]](#cite_note-Guardian-Guardiola-64) It was the 15th occasion a club [won the European Cup unbeaten](/wiki/European_Cup_and_UEFA_Champions_League_records_and_statistics#Unbeaten_sides "European Cup and UEFA Champions League records and statistics"), with City the 11th club to ac ...

The **2025 UEFA Champions League final** was the final match of the [2024–25 UEFA Champions League](/wiki/2024%E2%80%9325_UEFA_Champions_League "2024–25 UEFA Champions League"), the 70th season of Europe's premier club football tournament organised by [UEFA](/wiki/UEFA "UEFA"), and the 33rd season since it was renamed from the [European Champion Clubs' Cup](/wiki/European_Champion_Clubs%27_Cup "European Champion Clubs' Cup") to the [UEFA Champions League](/wiki/UEFA_Champions_League "UEFA Champions League"). It was held at the [Allianz Arena](/wiki/Allianz_Arena "Allianz Arena") in [Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich"), Germany, on 31 May 2025, between French club [Paris Saint-Germain](/wiki/Paris_Saint-Germain_FC "Paris Saint-Germain FC") and Italian club [Inter Milan](/wiki/Inter_Milan "Inter Milan").

Paris Saint-Germain won the match 5–0 for their first European Cup title,[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) marking the second final victory by a French club since [Marseille](/wiki/Olympique_de_Marseille "Olympique de Marseille") in [1993](/wiki/1993_UEFA_Champions_League_final "1993 UEFA Champions League final"). Their margin of victory was the largest in any of the main European men's club competitions[\[a\]](#cite_note-major-6) final, with their goal tally only surpassed in one [European Cup final](/wiki/List_of_European_Cup_and_UEFA_Champions_League_finals "List of European Cup and UEFA Champions League finals") by [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_CF "Real Madrid CF")'s seven in [1960](/wiki/1960_European_Cup_final "1960 European Cup final"). In doing so, Paris Saint-Germain completed a [continental treble](/wiki/Treble_\(association_football\)#Continental_trebles "Treble (association football)"), the first of a French club, while [Luis Enrique](/wiki/Luis_Enrique "Luis Enrique") became the second manager since [Pep Guardiola](/wiki/Pep_Guardiola "Pep Guardiola") to have won the treble twice. As winners, Paris Saint-Germain earned the right to play against [Tottenham Hotspur](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C. "Tottenham Hotspur F.C."), winners of the [2024–25 UEFA Europa League](/wiki/2024%E2%80%9325_UEFA_Europa_League "2024–25 UEFA Europa League"), in the [2025 UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/2025_UEFA_Super_Cup "2025 UEFA Super Cup"), and automatically qualified for the [2025 FIFA Intercontinental Cup](/wiki/2025_FIFA_Intercontinental_Cup "2025 FIFA Intercontinental Cup") and the [2029 FIFA Club World Cup](/wiki/2029_FIFA_Club_World_Cup "2029 FIFA Club World Cup"). The match would also be [Simone Inzaghi](/wiki/Simone_Inzaghi "Simone Inzaghi")'s final match as manager of Inter Milan as he would leave his post three days after the final by mutual consent.

Background
----------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2025_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=1 "Edit section: Background")\]

Paris Saint-Germain reached their second Champions League final and the first since [2020](/wiki/2020_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2020 UEFA Champions League final"), when they lost to [Bayern Munich](/wiki/FC_Bayern_Munich "FC Bayern Munich").[\[6\]](#cite_note-7) This was the fifth European final for them, having previously also appeared in two consecutive finals of the [UEFA Cup Winners' Cup](/wiki/UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup "UEFA Cup Winners' Cup"), winning the [1996 final](/wiki/1996_UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup_final "1996 UEFA Cup Winners' Cup final") 1–0 against [Rapid Wien](/wiki/SK_Rapid_Wien "SK Rapid Wien") before losing by the same scoreline against [Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona") while attempting to defend their title in [1997](/wiki/1997_UEFA_Cup_Winners%27_Cup_final "1997 UEFA Cup Winners' Cup final").[\[7\]](#cite_note-8) The club also contested the [1996 UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/1996_UEFA_Super_Cup "1996 UEFA Super Cup"), losing 9–2 on aggregate to [Juventus](/wiki/Juventus_FC "Juventus FC"). Paris Saint-Germain attempted to become only the second French team to win the European Cup/Champions League, following the success of [their rivals](/wiki/Le_Classique "Le Classique") [Marseille](/wiki/Olympique_de_Marseille "Olympique de Marseille") in [1993](/wiki/1993_UEFA_Champions_League_final "1993 UEFA Champions League final")—with the final also taking place in Munich—and the first French club to complete a [continental treble](/wiki/Treble_\(association_football\)#Continental_trebles "Treble (association football)"), having won the [Ligue 1](/wiki/2024%E2%80%9325_Ligue_1 "2024–25 Ligue 1") and the [Coupe de France](/wiki/2024%E2%80%9325_Coupe_de_France "2024–25 Coupe de France").[\[8\]](#cite_note-treble-9) The club had won the [Trophée des Champions](/wiki/2024_Troph%C3%A9e_des_Champions "2024 Trophée des Champions") (super cup) earlier in the season, thus had a chance for a clean sweep of titles available to them.[\[9\]](#cite_note-10) Their manager, [Luis Enrique](/wiki/Luis_Enrique "Luis Enrique"), was aiming for a second continental treble, having done so with Barcelona in the [2014–15 season](/wiki/2014%E2%80%9315_FC_Barcelona_season "2014–15 FC Barcelona season"). Since he was successful, he became the second manager to achieve such a feat after fellow former Barcelona player and manager [Pep Guardiola](/wiki/Pep_Guardiola "Pep Guardiola"), who achieved so in [2008–09](/wiki/2008%E2%80%9309_FC_Barcelona_season "2008–09 FC Barcelona season") with Barcelona and in [2022–23](/wiki/2022%E2%80%9323_Manchester_City_F.C._season "2022–23 Manchester City F.C. season") with [Manchester City](/wiki/Manchester_City_F.C. "Manchester City F.C.").[\[8\]](#cite_note-treble-9) He also became the seventh [manager to win the European Cup/Champions League](/wiki/List_of_European_Cup_and_UEFA_Champions_League_winning_managers "List of European Cup and UEFA Champions League winning managers") with different clubs.[\[10\]](#cite_note-11)

This was Inter Milan's thirteenth European final and seventh European Cup/Champions League final appearance, having won 3–1 in [1964](/wiki/1964_European_Cup_final "1964 European Cup final") against [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_CF "Real Madrid CF"), 1–0 against [Benfica](/wiki/S.L._Benfica "S.L. Benfica") at [home](/wiki/San_Siro "San Siro") in [1965](/wiki/1965_European_Cup_final "1965 European Cup final") and 2–0 against Bayern Munich in [2010](/wiki/2010_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2010 UEFA Champions League final"), resulting in Inter completing the continental treble; they also lost 2–1 to [Celtic](/wiki/Celtic_F.C. "Celtic F.C.") in [1967](/wiki/1967_European_Cup_final "1967 European Cup final"), 2–0 to [Ajax](/wiki/AFC_Ajax "AFC Ajax") in [1972](/wiki/1972_European_Cup_final "1972 European Cup final") and 1–0 to Manchester City in [2023](/wiki/2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2023 UEFA Champions League final"),[\[11\]](#cite_note-RSSSF-12) all of which enabled those clubs to win the continental treble themselves.[\[8\]](#cite_note-treble-9) The club had also contested five UEFA Cup/UEFA Europa League finals, winning in [1991](/wiki/1991_UEFA_Cup_final "1991 UEFA Cup final"), [1994](/wiki/1994_UEFA_Cup_final "1994 UEFA Cup final"), and [1998](/wiki/1998_UEFA_Cup_final "1998 UEFA Cup final") as well as losing in [1997](/wiki/1997_UEFA_Cup_final "1997 UEFA Cup final") and [2020](/wiki/2020_UEFA_Europa_League_final "2020 UEFA Europa League final").[\[12\]](#cite_note-UC-13) They also contested the [2010 UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/2010_UEFA_Super_Cup "2010 UEFA Super Cup"), losing 2–0 to [Atlético Madrid](/wiki/Atl%C3%A9tico_Madrid "Atlético Madrid").[\[13\]](#cite_note-14) Inter Milan were the most recent Italian club to win the Champions League; since 2010 only one other Italian club—[their rivals](/wiki/Derby_d%27Italia "Derby d'Italia") Juventus—had reached the Champions League final, losing in [2015](/wiki/2015_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2015 UEFA Champions League final") and [2017](/wiki/2017_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2017 UEFA Champions League final").[\[11\]](#cite_note-RSSSF-12) [Simone Inzaghi](/wiki/Simone_Inzaghi "Simone Inzaghi") was aiming for his first European title as manager and the second in his football career, having won against [Manchester United](/wiki/Manchester_United_F.C. "Manchester United F.C.") in the [1999 UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/1999_UEFA_Super_Cup "1999 UEFA Super Cup") as a [Lazio](/wiki/SS_Lazio "SS Lazio") player.[\[14\]](#cite_note-15) Their midfielder [Henrikh Mkhitaryan](/wiki/Henrikh_Mkhitaryan "Henrikh Mkhitaryan") was aiming to become the eleventh player to have [won all three major European trophies](/wiki/UEFA_club_competition_records_and_statistics#List_of_players_to_have_won_the_three_main_European_club_competitions "UEFA club competition records and statistics") and the first to have achieved that with three different clubs, having won the [2016–17 UEFA Europa League](/wiki/2016%E2%80%9317_UEFA_Europa_League "2016–17 UEFA Europa League") with Manchester United and the [2021–22 UEFA Europa Conference League](/wiki/2021%E2%80%9322_UEFA_Europa_Conference_League "2021–22 UEFA Europa Conference League") with [Roma](/wiki/AS_Roma "AS Roma").[\[15\]](#cite_note-16)

The clubs had never met in any competitive matches, but had faced each other in five exhibition games.[\[16\]](#cite_note-17)

The match was the first Champions League final without a club from England, Spain or Germany since Portuguese side [Porto](/wiki/FC_Porto "FC Porto") defeated French representative [Monaco](/wiki/AS_Monaco_FC "AS Monaco FC") in [2004](/wiki/2004_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2004 UEFA Champions League final").[\[11\]](#cite_note-RSSSF-12)

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dc/Allianz_Arena_%28Bayern_Munich%29.jpg/330px-Allianz_Arena_%28Bayern_Munich%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Allianz_Arena_\(Bayern_Munich\).jpg)

The [Allianz Arena](/wiki/Allianz_Arena "Allianz Arena") in [Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich") hosted the final.

This was the second UEFA Champions League final hosted at the [Allianz Arena](/wiki/Allianz_Arena "Allianz Arena") in [Munich](/wiki/Munich "Munich"); the first was held in [2012](/wiki/2012_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2012 UEFA Champions League final").[\[17\]](#cite_note-18) Overall, it was the fifth [European Cup final](/wiki/List_of_European_Cup_and_UEFA_Champions_League_finals "List of European Cup and UEFA Champions League finals") to be held in Munich, with the [1979](/wiki/1979_European_Cup_final "1979 European Cup final"), [1993](/wiki/1993_UEFA_Champions_League_final "1993 UEFA Champions League final"), [1997](/wiki/1997_UEFA_Champions_League_final "1997 UEFA Champions League final"), and [2012](/wiki/2012_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2012 UEFA Champions League final") finals taking place at the [Olympiastadion](/wiki/Olympiastadion_\(Munich\) "Olympiastadion (Munich)"). Each of the previous four finals played in Munich saw a first-time winner of the competition crowned ([Nottingham Forest](/wiki/Nottingham_Forest_F.C. "Nottingham Forest F.C.") in 1979, [Marseille](/wiki/Olympique_de_Marseille "Olympique de Marseille") in 1993, [Borussia Dortmund](/wiki/Borussia_Dortmund "Borussia Dortmund") in 1997, and [Chelsea](/wiki/Chelsea_F.C. "Chelsea F.C.") in 2012). The final also was the ninth to take place in Germany, having also taken place in [Stuttgart](/wiki/Stuttgart "Stuttgart") in [1959](/wiki/1959_European_Cup_final "1959 European Cup final") and [1988](/wiki/1988_European_Cup_final "1988 European Cup final"), [Gelsenkirchen](/wiki/Gelsenkirchen "Gelsenkirchen") in [2004](/wiki/2004_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2004 UEFA Champions League final") and [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin "Berlin") in [2015](/wiki/2015_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2015 UEFA Champions League final"), equalling the record of nine European Cup finals held in Italy and England.[\[18\]](#cite_note-19) The Allianz Arena previously hosted matches at the [2006 FIFA World Cup](/wiki/2006_FIFA_World_Cup "2006 FIFA World Cup"),[\[19\]](#cite_note-StadiaNames-20) and was chosen as a host venue for [UEFA Euro 2020](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2020 "UEFA Euro 2020") and [UEFA Euro 2024](/wiki/UEFA_Euro_2024 "UEFA Euro 2024").

### Host selection

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2025_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Host selection")\]

On 16 July 2021, the UEFA Executive Committee announced that the [Atatürk Olympic Stadium](/wiki/Atat%C3%BCrk_Olympic_Stadium "Atatürk Olympic Stadium") in [Istanbul](/wiki/Istanbul "Istanbul") would host the [2023 UEFA Champions League final](/wiki/2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2023 UEFA Champions League final") instead of Munich.[\[20\]](#cite_note-Munich_2025-21) This was because Istanbul twice had the Champions League final intended for their city relocated due to the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic "COVID-19 pandemic"). Originally planned as hosts for the [2020 final](/wiki/2020_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2020 UEFA Champions League final"), the match was moved to [Lisbon](/wiki/Lisbon "Lisbon") and the final hosts shifted back a year, with Istanbul instead awarded the [2021 final](/wiki/2021_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2021 UEFA Champions League final").[\[21\]](#cite_note-22) However, weeks prior to the final, the 2021 fixture was moved to [Porto](/wiki/Porto "Porto") due to travel restrictions.[\[22\]](#cite_note-Porto-23)

Munich, originally selected to host the [2022 final](/wiki/2022_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2022 UEFA Champions League final") by the UEFA Executive Committee during their meeting in [Ljubljana](/wiki/Ljubljana "Ljubljana"), Slovenia on 24 September 2019,[\[23\]](#cite_note-24) was later planned to host the [2023 final](/wiki/2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2023 UEFA Champions League final") after the shifting of the final hosts. However, the city was awarded the 2025 final instead after being bumped from 2023 by Istanbul.[\[20\]](#cite_note-Munich_2025-21)

Pre-match
---------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2025_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=6 "Edit section: Pre-match")\]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Linkin_Park_-_From_Zero_Lead_Press_Photo_-_James_Minchin_III.jpg/250px-Linkin_Park_-_From_Zero_Lead_Press_Photo_-_James_Minchin_III.jpg)](/wiki/File:Linkin_Park_-_From_Zero_Lead_Press_Photo_-_James_Minchin_III.jpg)

[Linkin Park](/wiki/Linkin_Park "Linkin Park"), the headline act of the opening ceremony.

The visual identity of the 2025 UEFA Champions League final was unveiled on 28 January 2025.[\[25\]](#cite_note-26) On 16 April, American rock band [Linkin Park](/wiki/Linkin_Park "Linkin Park") was named as the headline act of the opening ceremony.[\[26\]](#cite_note-27) On 26 May, German violinist [David Garrett](/wiki/David_Garrett "David Garrett") was announced to play a rearranged version of [the White Stripes](/wiki/The_White_Stripes "The White Stripes")' "[Seven Nation Army](/wiki/Seven_Nation_Army "Seven Nation Army")" on the trophy presentation prior to the teams' entrance.[\[27\]](#cite_note-28)

### Summary

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2025_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Summary")\]
