[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Doue_asse_psg_2425.png/250px-Doue_asse_psg_2425.png)](/wiki/File:Doue_asse_psg_2425.png)

[Désiré Doué](/wiki/D%C3%A9sir%C3%A9_Dou%C3%A9 "Désiré Doué"), scorer of a brace in the final, was named [man of the match](/wiki/Man_of_the_match "Man of the match").

Paris Saint-Germain started the match by pressuring Inter and with high intensity.[\[28\]](#cite_note-kicker-29) In the 12th minute, [Vitinha](/wiki/Vitinha_\(footballer,_born_February_2000\) "Vitinha (footballer, born February 2000)") threaded a pass to Doué inside the box, who then found the unmarked [Achraf Hakimi](/wiki/Achraf_Hakimi "Achraf Hakimi") near the back post, slotting the ball in to give Paris an early lead. Their second goal came eight minutes later, with Willian Pacho acrobatically clearing the ball on the end line to start a counterattack. [Ousmane Dembélé](/wiki/Ousmane_Demb%C3%A9l%C3%A9 "Ousmane Dembélé") was found down the pitch, who then crossed the ball to Doué on the edge of the box, whose shot was deflected off [Federico Dimarco](/wiki/Federico_Dimarco "Federico Dimarco") and past a helpless [Yann Sommer](/wiki/Yann_Sommer "Yann Sommer"). Inter Milan missed opportunities to cut the deficit before half-time, with [Francesco Acerbi](/wiki/Francesco_Acerbi "Francesco Acerbi") (23') and [Marcus Thuram](/wiki/Marcus_Thuram "Marcus Thuram") (37') missing their headers. Paris Saint-Germain also had additional opportunities before the break, with Dembelé (44') and [Khvicha Kvaratskhelia](/wiki/Khvicha_Kvaratskhelia "Khvicha Kvaratskhelia") (45+2') missing both.[\[29\]](#cite_note-:0-30)

In the first minute of the second half, Paris Saint-Germain's Kvaratskhelia missed a shot. Inter Milan's [Hakan Çalhanoğlu](/wiki/Hakan_%C3%87alhano%C4%9Flu "Hakan Çalhanoğlu") then took a free kick but hit the ball wide. In the 50th minute, Inter's [Nicolò Barella](/wiki/Nicol%C3%B2_Barella "Nicolò Barella") protested to the referee that [Marquinhos](/wiki/Marquinhos "Marquinhos") had committed a handball offence, but the referee disagreed and did not give a penalty. Inter took off [Benjamin Pavard](/wiki/Benjamin_Pavard "Benjamin Pavard") and Dimarco, and replaced them with [Yann Bisseck](/wiki/Yann_Bisseck "Yann Bisseck") and [Nicola Zalewski](/wiki/Nicola_Zalewski "Nicola Zalewski"). Two minutes after coming on, Zalewski was booked for a slide tackle on [Fabián Ruiz](/wiki/Fabi%C3%A1n_Ruiz "Fabián Ruiz"). In the 58th minute, Inter Milan's head coach [Simone Inzaghi](/wiki/Simone_Inzaghi "Simone Inzaghi") was booked for protesting one of the referee's decisions. In the 61st minute, Inter made two more substitutions, [Matteo Darmian](/wiki/Matteo_Darmian "Matteo Darmian") and [Carlos Augusto](/wiki/Carlos_Augusto_\(footballer\) "Carlos Augusto (footballer)") for Mkhitaryan and Bisseck (who was brought off after a knee [hyperextension](/wiki/Hyperextension "Hyperextension")). Two minutes later, Paris Saint-Germain scored a third goal with Doué finding the net after a through ball from Vitinha following a counterattack started by Dembele and Vitinha; Doué was booked for removing his shirt as his celebration. In the 67th minute, he was replaced by [Bradley Barcola](/wiki/Bradley_Barcola "Bradley Barcola"). In the 69th minute, Thuram was booked for a foul on Ruiz, as was Acerbi four minutes later. Inter Milan made another substitution in the 69th minute with [Kristjan Asllani](/wiki/Kristjan_Asllani "Kristjan Asllani") replacing Çalhanoğlu. In the 73rd minute, Kvaratskhelia scored a fourth goal for Paris Saint-Germain, after a through ball from Dembélé to get behind Inter's defense near the halfway line. Three minutes later, Thuram got Inter's first shot on target of the match, but the ball was caught by goalkeeper [Gianluigi Donnarumma](/wiki/Gianluigi_Donnarumma "Gianluigi Donnarumma"). Paris Saint-Germain went on to make more substitutions: [Nuno Mendes](/wiki/Nuno_Mendes_\(footballer,_born_2002\) "Nuno Mendes (footballer, born 2002)") was replaced by [Lucas Hernandez](/wiki/Lucas_Hernandez "Lucas Hernandez"), and then Kvaratskhelia, [João Neves](/wiki/Jo%C3%A3o_Neves "João Neves"), and Ruiz were substituted for [Gonçalo Ramos](/wiki/Gon%C3%A7alo_Ramos "Gonçalo Ramos"), [Warren Zaïre-Emery](/wiki/Warren_Za%C3%AFre-Emery "Warren Zaïre-Emery"), and [Senny Mayulu](/wiki/Senny_Mayulu "Senny Mayulu"), who scored the fifth goal of the game from a tight angle just three minutes after coming on.[\[29\]](#cite_note-:0-30)

Post-match
----------

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2025_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Post-match")\]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/2015_UEFA_Super_Cup_66.jpg/250px-2015_UEFA_Super_Cup_66.jpg)](/wiki/File:2015_UEFA_Super_Cup_66.jpg)

Paris Saint-Germain's [Luis Enrique](/wiki/Luis_Enrique "Luis Enrique") won both his second Champions League title and continental treble as manager.

With their victory, Paris Saint-Germain won their first European Cup title, the 24th team to do so. It also marked the second final to be won by a French club, after [Marseille](/wiki/Olympique_de_Marseille "Olympique de Marseille") in [1993](/wiki/1993_UEFA_Champions_League_final "1993 UEFA Champions League final").[\[11\]](#cite_note-RSSSF-12) Paris Saint-Germain also completed the eleventh [continental treble](/wiki/Treble_\(association_football\)#Continental_trebles "Treble (association football)") in European football history, doing so as the ninth overall team and first French club.[\[8\]](#cite_note-treble-9) It was the [fourth trophy of the season](/wiki/List_of_association_football_teams_to_have_won_four_or_more_trophies_in_one_season#Four_titles_in_one_season "List of association football teams to have won four or more trophies in one season") for Paris Saint-Germain, having also won the [Trophée des Champions](/wiki/2024_Troph%C3%A9e_des_Champions "2024 Trophée des Champions"). [Luis Enrique](/wiki/Luis_Enrique "Luis Enrique") won his second Champions League title as manager, having previously won with [Barcelona](/wiki/FC_Barcelona "FC Barcelona") in [2015](/wiki/2015_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2015 UEFA Champions League final") as part of a treble. With the victory, he became the 21st coach to win multiple finals and the seventh to do so with multiple clubs.[\[34\]](#cite_note-35) Additionally, he became the second manager to win multiple trebles after fellow Spaniard [Pep Guardiola](/wiki/Pep_Guardiola "Pep Guardiola"), who also won his first treble with Barcelona.[\[8\]](#cite_note-treble-9)

Paris Saint-Germain's five unanswered goals set a record for the largest margin of victory in the final of any of the main European men's club competitions;[\[a\]](#cite_note-major-6) for a European Cup final, this result surpassed the four-goal differences in [1960](/wiki/1960_European_Cup_final "1960 European Cup final"), [1974 replay](/wiki/1974_European_Cup_final#Replay "1974 European Cup final"), [1989](/wiki/1989_European_Cup_final "1989 European Cup final") and [1994](/wiki/1994_UEFA_Champions_League_final "1994 UEFA Champions League final").[\[37\]](#cite_note-38) It also equaled, with [Benfica](/wiki/S.L._Benfica "S.L. Benfica") in [1962](/wiki/1962_European_Cup_final "1962 European Cup final"), for the second-most goals scored by a team in the final, only behind the seven of [Real Madrid](/wiki/Real_Madrid_CF "Real Madrid CF") in 1960.[\[11\]](#cite_note-RSSSF-12) [Senny Mayulu](/wiki/Senny_Mayulu "Senny Mayulu") became the second-youngest scorer in a Champions League final, only behind [Patrick Kluivert](/wiki/Patrick_Kluivert "Patrick Kluivert") in [1995](/wiki/1995_UEFA_Champions_League_final "1995 UEFA Champions League final"), while [Désiré Doué](/wiki/D%C3%A9sir%C3%A9_Dou%C3%A9 "Désiré Doué") became the fourth-youngest.[\[38\]](#cite_note-39) Doué was named as the [man of the match](/wiki/Man_of_the_match "Man of the match") for his brace,[\[1\]](#cite_note-MOTM-1) and was subsequently selected as the Champions League Young Player of the Season.[\[39\]](#cite_note-40) The win for Paris Saint-Germain also meant for the first time since [Porto](/wiki/FC_Porto "FC Porto")'s win in the [2003–04 season](/wiki/2003%E2%80%9304_UEFA_Champions_League "2003–04 UEFA Champions League") that a club from outside of Europe's four big leagues (England, Spain, Italy, and Germany) had won the tournament.

Inter Milan's loss was their fourth in a Champions League final (after [1967](/wiki/1967_European_Cup_final "1967 European Cup final"), [1972](/wiki/1972_European_Cup_final "1972 European Cup final"), and [2023](/wiki/2023_UEFA_Champions_League_final "2023 UEFA Champions League final")) and the second in three seasons.[\[11\]](#cite_note-RSSSF-12) Having finished second in [Serie A](/wiki/2024%E2%80%9325_Serie_A "2024–25 Serie A") and the [Supercoppa Italiana](/wiki/2024_Supercoppa_Italiana "2024 Supercoppa Italiana") and exited the [Coppa Italia](/wiki/2024%E2%80%9325_Coppa_Italia "2024–25 Coppa Italia") in the semi-finals, the defeat meant Inter would finish a season without a trophy for the first time since the [2019–20 season](/wiki/2019%E2%80%9320_Inter_Milan_season "2019–20 Inter Milan season"), when they also lost a European final. Inter manager [Simone Inzaghi](/wiki/Simone_Inzaghi "Simone Inzaghi") called the defeat "painful" and "disappointing" but said Inter would bounce back from the loss like they did in 2023.[\[40\]](#cite_note-41) However, the final turned out to be Inzaghi's last game in charge of Inter as he left the club by mutual consent three days later.[\[41\]](#cite_note-42)

As winners, Paris Saint-Germain qualified for various other competitions. They competed in the [2025 UEFA Super Cup](/wiki/2025_UEFA_Super_Cup "2025 UEFA Super Cup") against [Tottenham Hotspur](/wiki/Tottenham_Hotspur_F.C. "Tottenham Hotspur F.C."), winners of the [2024–25 UEFA Europa League](/wiki/2024%E2%80%9325_UEFA_Europa_League "2024–25 UEFA Europa League"). They also qualified for the [final](/wiki/2025_FIFA_Intercontinental_Cup_final "2025 FIFA Intercontinental Cup final") of the [2025 FIFA Intercontinental Cup](/wiki/2025_FIFA_Intercontinental_Cup "2025 FIFA Intercontinental Cup"), where they will compete against another continental champions for the title of [annual club world champions](/wiki/List_of_world_champion_football_clubs "List of world champion football clubs").[\[42\]](#cite_note-43) Finally, they qualified for the [2029 FIFA Club World Cup](/wiki/2029_FIFA_Club_World_Cup "2029 FIFA Club World Cup"), FIFA's quadrennial club championship.[\[43\]](#cite_note-44)

### Celebrations and riots

\[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2025_UEFA_Champions_League_final&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Celebrations and riots")\]

Main article: [2025 Paris Saint-Germain celebration riots](/wiki/2025_Paris_Saint-Germain_celebration_riots "2025 Paris Saint-Germain celebration riots")

Following Paris Saint-Germain's victory, celebrations were held across France overnight. In some areas, [disorder broke out](/wiki/2025_Paris_Saint-Germain_celebration_riots "2025 Paris Saint-Germain celebration riots") and across the country two people were killed and a further 192 were injured, with 559 people being arrested. A 17-year-old boy died after being stabbed in [Dax](/wiki/Dax,_Landes "Dax, Landes") and a 23-year-old man was killed in central [Paris](/wiki/Paris "Paris") after being hit by a vehicle whilst riding a scooter. The [interior ministry](/wiki/Minister_of_the_Interior_\(France\) "Minister of the Interior (France)") said that 491 people were arrested in Paris alone and 264 vehicles were set on fire; among the injured were 22 police officers and seven firefighters. Four people were injured in [Grenoble](/wiki/Grenoble "Grenoble") after a car ploughed into PSG fans. During the celebrations shops were looted, bus shelters smashed and flares and fireworks set off, with clashes breaking out near the [Champs-Élysées](/wiki/Champs-%C3%89lys%C3%A9es "Champs-Élysées") and the [Parc des Princes](/wiki/Parc_des_Princes "Parc des Princes"). Around 5,400 police were deployed across Paris in anticipation of disorder during the celebrations, and [Paris police prefect](/wiki/Paris_Police_Prefecture "Paris Police Prefecture") said the trophy parade would go ahead the next day but with a higher police and military presence.[\[44\]](#cite_note-45)

{"code": "# Calculate the differences for Inter Milan (2025 - 2023)
inter_differences = {}

# Data that we have for both years
stats_with_data = [
    ('Possession (%)', 41, 43),
    ('Total attempts', 8, 14),
    ('Attempts on target', 2, 5),
    ('Attempts off target', 6, 9),
    ('Fouls committed', 7, 17),
    ('Offsides', 5, 1),
    ('Corners taken', 6, 4),
    ('Yellow cards', 4, 4)
]

differences_data = []
for stat_name, val_2025, val_2023 in stats_with_data:
    difference = val_2025 - val_2023
    differences_data.append([difference])
    print(f"{stat_name}: {val_2025} - {val_2023} = {difference}")

# For missing data, we'll put "missing"
missing_stats = [
    'Attacks',
    'Blocked', 
    'Passing accuracy (%)',
    'Passes completed',
    'Crosses completed',
    'Balls recovered',
    'Tackles',
    'Avg age of starting lineup',
    'Avg age of team'
]

print("\nDifferences data for StatsDifference sheet:")
print(differences_data)"}
